text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with how to make your own home
cured holiday ham that's right i was
going to spend this intro going over all
the advantages of doing your own ham
versus buying one at the store but you
know what that's going to take too long
so let me just summarize by saying it's
better on every level and this is one of
those classic examples of something
people assume is really hard and
complicated to do when in reality it's
actually very simple and easy assuming
that is you can get a hold of one fairly
easy to find specialty ingredient which
we will get to in a second but for now
let's get started with the brine and
what we're going to do is mix this up in
the container we're going to actually
brine the ham in so we are going to need
something big enough to fit in the meat
and this mixture and then into this
we'll dump our brine ingredients which
starts with a whole bunch of kosher salt
and yes we need that much we're also
going to add some brown sugar as well as
some spices and i'm going to cheat now
to package a pickling spice which has
bay leaf black pepper mustard seeds
coriander clove as well as some other
Ham friendly herbs and spices and then
last but not least a specialty
ingredient I mentioned earlier some pink
salts whoo check it out and no this is
not Himalayan pink salt this is a curing
salt that contains sodium nitrite and
this really is one of the keys to the
whole ham making process and don't worry
I'm going to give you a lot more info
about that I'm a blog post since there
are a few different kinds and it goes by
many different names but anyway what
we're going to do next is bring a couple
quarts of water to a boil and pour that
over our ingredients to dissolve them so
we'll dump that in we'll give it a stir
and then once that's been accomplished
what we'll do is add one gallon of fresh
cold water which is going to do two
things it's going to cool this mixture
down because we don't want to use this
until it's room temp and it's also more
importantly going to give us the right
proportion of water to salt and at this
point we'll just let that cool down to
room temp while we move on to the star
of the show the ham or more accurately
the large piece of pork that's going to
become the ham so what I have here is
about a 10 pound what they call an arm
picnic roast or a picnic shoulder which
is from the front of the animal but we
could also certainly use the leg from
the back which is actually the more
traditional cut but bottom line any
large chunk of pork is going to work
here and please note I'm using one
that's skin on
which means before this goes in the
brine we want to score that skin and all
that means is take a sharp knife and cut
through that skin into the fat but not
into the meat and I'm going to do that
about an inch apart all the way across
and then I'll turn that and go the other
way to get that sort of classic diamond
pattern and by the way I usually do
these without the skin but since our
last holiday ham video featured a
skinless version I thought I'd do this
with skin to show you a slightly
different technique and please don't
feel like you have to do yours as
perfectly as I did I've been scouring
for like 30 years so I'm pretty good at
it but as long as you're cutting through
that skin in enough spots it's going to
work fine and once our pork has been
successfully scored it's ready to
carefully lower to our now a totally
cooled brine and because of the high
concentration of salt in there that
meats going to want to float so we'll
want to weigh that down with a little
plate or in my case a little cooling
rack like this really anything that
keeps that under the surface is going to
work and believe it or not that's it the
only other ingredient needed here is the
most precious time so what we want to do
here is let this brine in the
refrigerator of course for one day per
every two pounds of meat and since I was
working with about a 10 pound roast I
let mine brine for five days so this is
mine five days later and yes you may
have noticed I did turn that over once
during the brining process so after
about three days I just flipped that
over and I'm not sure if you have to but
it feels right so at this point we can
go ahead and remove that from the brine
and we got to give it a rinse which I'm
going to do in this tub because I had
dishes in the sink
so all we'll do is fill that with nice
fresh cold water and let that sit in
there a few minutes and by the way this
rinsing in water is something I'm going
to also talk about on the blog because
this can be done from anywhere between a
few minutes and overnight but anyway
we'll give that a little soak to rinse
off the brine at which point we can dry
it off and get it ready for the oven
and as far as the cooking procedure goes
we'll start it off just like our other
hand video we'll place that on a rack in
a roasting pan which has a little bit of
water in the bottom as well as a couple
whole star knees and then we'll place
that in the center of a 325 degree oven
for a couple hours or until the internal
temperature
about 130 to 135 which is not fully
cooked yet and at that point your ham
should look something like this and by
the way if the water dries up on the
bottom just add another splash and then
what we're going to do at this point
because the ham is not quite cooked
we're going to raise the temperature to
425 and finish it the rest of the way in
a hot oven until the internal tap is
about 145 to 150 and at that point if
everything's gone according to plan it
should look something like this that
skin should have browned it got nice and
crispy and it definitely looks good
enough to serve as is but I decided to
give mine a quick maple mustard glaze so
what I'll do is brush a little bit of
that on mostly in those valleys between
those crispy squares of skin and I'll
just pop that back in the hot oven for
about five minutes after which you
should be even more beautiful which I
think this is except for one very small
problem I can see I have a little bit of
a bear spot and since all's fair in love
war and holiday hams I'm going to cheat
and add one more touch of glaze and then
I'm going to steal some crispy skin from
the side of the bottom where nobody's
going to notice it missing and I'm going
to strategically place a couple small
squares of that to fill in that hole
ensure this might seem a little
obsessive and possibly borderline insane
but hey at Margaret has like a thousand
mr. grant followers and we do not need
all those people staring at our hams
bear spot so I did a little cosmetic
surgery but that's totally up to you you
are the Fat Boy slim of your holiday ham
skin and not only does it look
impressive but thanks to finishing that
skin in the hot oven it also sounds
incredible check it out oh man is that
good and it is tempting to say that's
the best part but that beautiful meat
underneath was just as good so let me
slice a little bit so you can see what
we got going on here and no this is not
undercooked that pink colour is from
that curious all we used which also
helps give this its unique flavor and
beautiful firm texture and look how
moist and juicy that is this really was
amazing in fact it was so good I didn't
even bother making any side dishes I
just enjoyed my ham on a bare plate with
a little lecture my maple mustard glaze
on there which yes I'll tell you how to
do on the blog so let me go in here for
the final official taste sure if it's
possible if you try to smoke this
but even just baked in the oven it's
still magnificent in fact is a little
visual illustration regarding how much I
enjoyed this keep your eye on that
little strip of crispy skin as I take
this last bite in slow-mo oh yeah that
pretty much sums up how we feel about
this so anyway that's it how to make
your own home cured holiday ham sure
takes a few days but you have time and
it is very much an easy and fun process
so I really do hope you give this a try
soon head over to food wishes comm for
all the ingredient amounts and more as
usual and as always enjoy
